user_request: A poem for a wedding about soulmates and happily ever after.

revision_history.draft:
# The Janitor's Log

I sweep the third floor on Tuesday afternoons
and she walks past with her coffee cooling,
third button left undone, the way
certain glasses stay slightly tilted
on tables — held there by a force
less urgent than gravity.

The hallway has a water stain shaped like Ohio.
Not everyone notices. She does,
and she reads it the same way I read mail:
as something directed at me, even though
the buckeye is right-side up for no one else.

I have memorized her shoeprints — not which brand but how
the heel drags slightly on concrete, how the left foot
trusts the floor a little less than the right,
and the stain rearranges itself around both of them.

Today she stopped at the stairwell door,
fished something from her bag, and pressed it flat
against the glass — whatever it was,
a small square of mirror maybe, or just
the reflection of a light switch she'd forgotten to flip.

She stood there with one hand on the rail,
the other holding whatever, and the building
held still for what I later understood
to be the exact duration it takes
a room to become someone's memory.

I noticed because the broom clicked stone.
The clicking was nothing. What wasn't
nothing: how every sound in that corridor
after that became softer, carried,
the way a lake goes mute when a boat
pulls away and leaves only the shape
of its wake behind it.

I mention this to no one.
I have kept most of my years
mostly to myself. But on Wednesday I saw her again
and she was looking down at the sidewalk,
and there — just past her left foot, where the brick
had split a year ago and never quite closed —

there was Ohio too.

This time it was upside down.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The central conceit — a janitor witnessing someone through the lens of daily, unremarkable observation — is genuinely strong and specific enough to sustain a poem. The water stain shaped like Ohio, the way she reads it "as something directed at me," the shoeprints memorized down to asymmetry: these are precise, earned details that do real work. The final image of the state upside-down carries genuine weight because it arrives after building trust through accumulated attention.

The structural move from private observation (broom clicking stone) to a single moment where "every sound in that corridor / became softer, carried" is well-timed — the poem earns its quietness by accumulating noise first. That line about a lake going mute when a boat pulls away is one of the sharpest images here; it captures absence through physical analogy without stating "I was gone."

The stanza beginning "she stopped at the stairwell door" has real momentum: the fish-in-water metaphor (pressing something flat against glass, forgetting to flip the light switch) lands because it's concrete and slightly absurd. The poem is doing its best work in these last twenty lines.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché / sentimentality — "I mention this to no one" (lines 30–31).** This closing gesture is the weakest moment. It tells us the speaker is reticent and mysterious, but it's a stock move that asks for feeling without generating any. The poem has already shown us the reticence through the entire janitorial routine; "I mention this to no one" adds nothing new except an opportunity for vague admiration. **Direction:** Cut or replace with something as specific as what follows — the brick split, the state upside-down. The ending doesn't need to narrate its own importance.

**Abstraction — "a force / less urgent than gravity." (lines 7–8).** This is philosophy dressed in image-adjacent language. It explains rather than shows. **Direction:** Replace with a visual equivalent of that comparison, or cut the comparison entirely and let the coffee-mirroring image carry its own weight.

**Cliché — "the exact duration it takes / a room to become someone's memory." (lines 26–27).** This is a paraphrase of what the poem has been doing for twenty lines. The specificity of stone clicking, light dimming, the boat pulling away — that's already *the* duration. **Direction:** Remove or compress this line so the final image can breathe.

**Weak transition — "This time it was upside down" (line 37).** After the rich, physical detail of the brick and the state, this reversal arrives almost as a caption. It doesn't build from what came before; it summarizes. **Direction:** Consider ending on the image itself — let the reader discover

revision_history.draft:
# The Janitor's Log

I sweep the third floor on Tuesday afternoons
and she walks past with her coffee cooling,
the cup tilting not dramatically — more
like a gate that leans, then stays leaning,
the hinge worn soft by one direction.

The hallway has a water stain shaped like Ohio.
Not everyone notices. She does,
and she reads it the same way I read mail:
as something directed at me, even though
the buckeye is right-side up for no one else.

I have memorized her shoeprints — not which brand but how
the heel drags slightly on concrete, how the left foot
trusts the floor a little less than the right,
and the stain rearranges itself around both of them.

Today she stopped at the stairwell door,
fished something from her bag, and pressed it flat
against the glass — whatever it was,
a small square of mirror maybe, or just
the reflection of a light switch she'd forgotten to flip.

She stood there with one hand on the rail,
the other holding whatever, and the building
held still for what I later understood
to be the exact duration it takes
a room to become someone's memory.

The broom clicked stone.
That clicking was nothing. What wasn't
nothing: how every sound in that corridor
after that became softer, carried,
the way a lake goes mute when a boat
pulls away and leaves only the shape
of its wake behind it.

Today she was looking down at the sidewalk,
and there — just past her left foot, where the brick
had split a year ago and never quite closed —

there was Ohio too.

This time it was upside down.
revision_history.critique:
## Revision Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The final eight lines are the strongest work here. "There was Ohio too" — upside down — lands because it arrives after accumulating enough sensory detail that the reader has *felt* what the speaker felt, rather than been told about it. The boat pulling away from the lake is one of the sharpest images in the draft; it captures absence through physical analogy without stating "I was gone."

The stanza beginning "she stopped at the stairwell door" also works — the fish-in-water metaphor (pressing something flat against glass, forgetting to flip the light switch) lands because it's concrete and slightly absurd. The detail of the shoeprints ("how the left foot / trusts the floor a little less than the right") is precise and earns its place.

The structural move from private observation (broom clicking stone) to public quiet — "every sound in that corridor became softer, carried" — is well-timed: it builds toward something without explaining what.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché / sentimentality — "I mention this to no one." (lines 30–31).**
*Failure type:* The poem narrates its own importance rather than trusting the images. This is a closing gesture that asks for feeling without generating any.
*Direction:* Cut or replace with something as specific as what follows — the brick split, the state upside-down. The ending doesn't need to narrate its own significance.

**Abstraction — "a force / less urgent than gravity." (lines 7–8).**
*Failure type:* Philosophy dressed in image-adjacent language. It explains rather than shows.
*Direction:* Replace with a visual equivalent of that comparison, or cut the comparison entirely and let the coffee-mirroring image carry its own weight.

**Cliché — "the exact duration it takes / a room to become someone's memory." (lines 26–27).**
*Failure type:* A paraphrase of what the poem has been doing for twenty lines. The specificity of stone clicking, light dimming, the boat pulling away — that's already *the* duration.
*Direction:* Remove or compress this line so the final image can breathe.

**Weak transition — "This time it was upside down" (line 37).**
*Failure type:* After the rich, physical detail of the brick and the state, this reversal arrives almost as a caption. It summarizes rather than building.
*Direction:* Consider ending on the image itself — let the reader discover.

**Redundancy — "fished something from her bag" / "pressed it flat."**
*Failure type:* The poem describes fishing *and* pressing; one is enough. Both add vagueness.
*Direction:* Choose one or combine them into a single physical gesture that doesn't require explanation.

**Line count and compression.**
The draft runs

the cup tilting not dramatically — more

as something directed at me, even though

I have memorized her shoeprints — not which brand but how
the heel drags slightly on concrete, how the left foot
trusts the floor a little less than the right,
and the stain rearranges itself around both of them.

Today she stopped at the stairwell door,
fished a small square of mirror from her bag,
pressed it flat against the glass — whatever it was,
the reflection of a light switch she'd forgotten to flip.

She stood there with one hand on the rail,
the other holding nothing, and the building
held still for what I later understood
to be the exact duration it takes
a lake to go mute when a boat
pulls away and leaves only the shape
of its wake behind it.

Today she was looking down at the sidewalk,
and there — just past her left foot, where the brick
had split a year ago and never quite closed —

there was Ohio too.

## Workshop Response

---

### What's Alive

The final eight lines are the strongest work here. "There was Ohio too" — upside down — lands because it arrives after accumulating enough sensory detail that the reader has *felt* what the speaker felt, rather than been told about it. The boat pulling away from the lake is one of the sharpest images in the draft; it captures absence through physical analogy without explaining "I was gone."

The stanza beginning "she stopped at the stairwell door" also works — the fish-in-water metaphor (pressing something flat against glass, forgetting to flip the light switch) lands because it's concrete and slightly absurd. The detail of the shoeprints ("how the left foot / trusts the floor a little less than the right") is precise and earns its place.

The structural move from private observation (broom clicking stone) to public quiet — "every sound in that corridor became softer, carried," — is well-timed: it builds toward something without explaining what.

---

### What Isn't Working

**Cliché / sentimentality — "I mention this to no one." (lines 30–31).**
*Failure type:* The poem narrates its own importance rather than trusting the images. This is a closing gesture that asks for feeling without generating any.
*Direction:* Cut or replace with something as specific as what follows — the brick split, the state upside-down. The ending doesn't need to narrate its own significance.

**Abstraction — "a force / less urgent than gravity." (lines 7–8).**
*Failure type:* Philosophy dressed in image-adjacent language. It explains rather than shows.
*Direction:* Replace with a visual equivalent of that comparison, or cut the comparison entirely and let the coffee-mirroring image carry its own weight.

*Direction:* Remove or compress this line so the final image can breathe.

**Weak transition — "This time it was upside down" (line 37).**
*Failure type:* After the rich, physical detail of the brick and the state, this reversal arrives almost as a caption. It summarizes rather than builds.
*Direction:* Consider ending on the image itself — let the reader discover.

**Redundancy — "fished something from her bag" / "pressed it flat."**
*Failure type:* The poem describes fishing *and* pressing; one is enough. Both add vagueness.
*Direction:* Choose one or combine them into a single physical gesture that doesn't require explanation.

---

### Compress and Refine

The draft has earned its ending — now

revision_history.draft:
# The Janitor's Log

She walks past Tuesday
afternoons, coffee
cooling slightly,
the cup balanced like a gate
leaning one way.

I have memorized
how her heel drags
on the fourth-floor landing —
not afraid but slower
in the left foot's lane.

The hallway stain
is Ohio. She notices.
I notice she notice.
We don't mention it.
The buckeye leans
the same direction
as her shoeprint, both
against the floor's
worn evidence.

Today: she stops
at the stairwell door,
pulls a mirror from her bag — not large,
just enough to frame
the light switch she missed,
her hand trembling
only enough to shift
the reflection slightly left.

The building holds.
I mean the building. The way
a lake goes mute
when something heavy leaves it,
the surface keeping
the shape of what was there.

Brick dust on her shoe — I mean the dust
already split in February, I mean
she walks through it and the crack
arranges itself around her print,
like water remembering
a hand that closed too late.

Ohio. Again.
Just past her left foot,
where the mortar thinned —

the stain has moved
toward the exact shape
of what she didn't say.

final_poem:
She walks past Tuesday afternoons, coffee
cooling on the fourth-floor landing,
the cup tilted enough to make a small lake.

I have memorized how her heel drags
on the left side of the hallway's width—
not afraid but slower, in the lane
she's worn narrower than the others.

There is a stain here shaped like Ohio.
She notices it before I do. We don't mention it,
but her hand trembles slightly holding
the light switch above the stairwell door,
just enough to shift the reflection left.

The hallway holds its breath around her prints—
brick dust splitting open like water
remembering a hand that closed too late,
her shoe pushing through the thin mortar
where Ohio's leaf pushed years ago.

Today she stops at the landing, pulls out
a mirror no one packed with the furniture.
She checks the switch plate, corrects
the light's position in its frame,
and her thumb leaves a white mark
on the glass, on the floor, on everything
she didn't carry up the stairs.

The coffee has gone dark. Her heel
has learned to drag the left side only,
a habit I mean in the way
a lake goes mute when something heavy leaves it—
the surface keeping the shape
of what was there, even after.

She passes with her cup tilted.
I watch the water move
around her print: a stain
thinning toward the exact shape
of what she didn't say.
